questions.text: Staph. aureus causes vomiting in 6–8 hours. The mechanism of action is:
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Vagal stimulation

questions.text: Which of the following is ovo-viviparous?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Strongyloidis stercoralis

questions.text: Patient presents with cough and rusty sputum. On examination, lower lobe consolidation and bronchial breath sounds were heard. The sample gives a positive Quellung reaction. What is the probable Gram staining appearance?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gram +ve cocci

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of lobar pneumonia, rusty sputum, and a positive Quellung reaction points to Streptococcus pneumoniae , which is Gram-positive diplococci in appearance on Gram staining.
  • ➤ lobar pneumonia, rusty sputum, and a positive Quellung reaction
  • ➤ Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • ➤ Gram-positive diplococci

questions.text: A female had a thorn prick 5 years ago. She presented with a slowly growing 2 × 2 cm verrucous lesion which on KOH mount showed the following image:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chromoblastomycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chromoblastomycosis is characterized by verrucous lesions and the presence of sclerotic bodies (Medlar bodies) in KOH mounts, often following trauma like thorn pricks.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents with fever and altered sensorium for two days with the following rash on legs. Her BP is 70/50 mm Hg, and neck stiffness is present. Lumbar puncture reveals cloudy turbid CSF with 4200 cells/uL, Protein level 168, and Glucose of 21 mg/dL. Which of the following correctly describes the organism causing this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Gram Negative Diplococci (kidney shaped), Oxidase positive

options.label: B
options.text: Gram Negative Diplococci, ferments glucose and maltose

options.label: C
options.text: Gram Positive cocci catalase negative, bacitracin sensitive

options.label: D
options.text: Gram Positive Diplococci (lanceolate), catalase negative, optochin sensitive

questions.correct_answer: B. Gram Negative Diplococci, ferments glucose and maltose
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gram Negative Diplococci, ferments glucose and maltose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neisseria meningitidis is a Gram-negative diplococcus that ferments glucose and maltose and is a common cause of meningitis associated with a purpuric rash and the potential for rapid progression to septic shock, such as Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome.

questions.text: With which of the following viral hepatitis infections in pregnancy is the maternal mortality highest?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hepatitis E

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatitis E is the viral hepatitis infection that carries the highest risk of maternal mortality during pregnancy, particularly due to the risk of fulminant hepatic failure in the third trimester .
  • ➤ Hepatitis E
  • ➤ highest risk of maternal mortality
  • ➤ fulminant hepatic failure
  • ➤ third trimester

questions.text: XDR-TB is defined as:

options.label: D
options.text: Resistant to INH + Rifampicin + Amikacin + Ofloxacin

questions.correct_answer: D. Resistant to INH + Rifampicin + Amikacin + Ofloxacin
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Resistant to INH + Rifampicin + Amikacin + Ofloxacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ XDR-TB is defined as MDR-TB (resistance to INH and rifampicin) plus resistance to one fluoroquinolone and one injectable second-line aminoglycoside (e.g., amikacin). Recognizing the definition is crucial for understanding the severity and treatment challenges of drug-resistant tuberculosis.
  • ➤ XDR-TB
  • ➤ MDR-TB
  • ➤ plus resistance to one fluoroquinolone
  • ➤ one injectable second-line aminoglycoside

questions.text: A hospital worker is found to be HBsAg (+) ve. Further serum investigations showed HBe (+) ve and IgG anti-HBc (+) ve. The given hospital worker is?

options.label: A
options.text: Acute Hepatitis B patient with High infectivity

questions.correct_answer: C. Chronic infection with high infectivity
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Chronic infection with high infectivity

questions.text: An HIV+ve patient with CD4 Count 20 cells/mm³ came with complaints of headache, mild neck stiffness, and weakness suspected Meningitis, lumbar puncture revealed yeast with no pseudohyphae. India ink preparation shows capsule. Diagnosis:
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Cryptococcus

questions.text: A 7-month-old infant with the history of incomplete childhood vaccination presents with bouts of spasmodic cough with cyanosis and a typical inspiratory whoop. Which is the most appropriate clinical specimen to be collected for the isolation of pathogen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nasopharyngeal swab

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The nasopharyngeal swab is the most appropriate clinical specimen for isolating Bordetella pertussis in cases of suspected whooping cough, as it effectively captures the pathogen from the primary site of infection.

questions.text: There has been an outbreak of foodborne Salmonella gastroenteritis in the community and stool samples have been received in the laboratory. Which is the enrichment medium of choice?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Selenite ‘F’ medium

questions.text: A stool examination was carried out which showed an organism with darting motility. Which of the following organisms may be present in the stool?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Campylobacter jejuni

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Darting motility in stool samples is a key identifying feature of Campylobacter jejuni , making it the correct answer in this scenario. This characteristic motility helps in differentiating Campylobacter from other bacteria during stool microscopy.
  • ➤ Darting motility
  • ➤ Campylobacter jejuni

questions.text: All are true about Chagas’ disease except:

options.label: A
options.text: Romana's sign is a diagnostic feature of acute Chagas’ disease

options.label: B
options.text: Tsetse fly is the vector (Glossina palpalis)

questions.correct_answer: B. Tsetse fly is the vector (Glossina palpalis)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Tsetse fly is the vector (Glossina palpalis)

questions.text: A farmer who is also having dairy farm with history of handling cows, presented to the dermatology OPD with ulcer over forearm with central black eschar. True statement regarding the likely causative organism:
questions.explanation: Ans. B) McFadyean's reaction positive

questions.text: Ziemann dots:
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Plasmodium malariae

questions.text: Terminal spined eggs are seen in:
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Schistosoma haematobium

questions.text: True about polio:

options.label: C
options.text: IM injections and increased muscular activity lead to increased paralysis

options.label: D
options.text: Polio drops given only in < 3 year

questions.correct_answer: C. IM injections and increased muscular activity lead to increased paralysis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) IM injections and increased muscular activity lead to increased paralysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IM injections and increased muscular activity during an acute poliovirus infection can lead to a greater risk of developing paralysis, making these factors significant considerations in the management of poliomyelitis.
  • ➤ IM injections
  • ➤ increased muscular activity

questions.text: All of the following interactions occur between antigen-antibody reactions except:
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Covalent bond

questions.text: Identify the vector involved in the spread of the disease, whose peripheral smear is as given:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ixodid tick

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Maltese cross formation seen in red blood cells is a hallmark of Babesiosis , and the disease is transmitted by the Ixodid tick (Ixodes scapularis). Recognizing this structure in a blood smear is critical for diagnosing Babesiosis.
  • ➤ Maltese cross formation
  • ➤ Babesiosis
  • ➤ Ixodid tick

questions.text: A 25-year-old female complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge, and bilateral nasal blockage for 2 years. She has a history of asthma and allergy. On examination, multiple ethmoidal polyps are noted with mucosal thickening and impacted secretions in both nasal cavities. A biopsy is taken, and the material is cultured, showing the growth of many hyphae and pseudohyphae with dichotomous branching typically at 45°. Which of the following is the most likely responsible organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aspergillus fumigatus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of septate hyphae with 45° dichotomous branching in the culture of sinus biopsy material is highly indicative of Aspergillus species, particularly Aspergillus fumigatus.

questions.text: Strawberry cervix is seen in:
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Trichomonas vaginalis

questions.text: An anxious mother brought her 4-year-old daughter to the pediatrician. The girl was passing loose, bulky stools for the past 20 days, often associated with pain in the abdomen. The pediatrician ordered a stool examination, which showed the following organisms. Identify the organism:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Giardia lamblia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Giardia lamblia causes malabsorption and chronic diarrhea in children, often associated with loose, bulky stools . The trophozoite form of Giardia is easily recognized by its pear shape , two nuclei , and flagella , making it distinguishable under the microscope.
  • ➤ Giardia lamblia
  • ➤ malabsorption
  • ➤ chronic diarrhea
  • ➤ loose, bulky stools
  • ➤ pear shape
  • ➤ two nuclei
  • ➤ flagella

questions.text: Correct sequence of the bacterial growth curve:

options.label: A
options.text: Log phase – Lag Phase – Stationary phase – Decline phase

options.label: B
options.text: Lag Phase – Log phase – Stationary phase – Decline phase

options.label: C
options.text: Stationary phase – Log phase – Lag Phase – Decline phase

options.label: D
options.text: Lag phase – Exponential phase – Log phase – Death phase

questions.correct_answer: B. Lag Phase – Log phase – Stationary phase – Decline phase
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lag Phase – Log phase – Stationary phase – Decline phase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of the bacterial growth curve is: Lag Phase – Log Phase – Stationary Phase – Decline Phase.

questions.text: A farmer presenting with fever off and on for the past 4 years was diagnosed to be suffering from chronic brucellosis. All of the following serological tests would be helpful in the diagnosis at this stage except:
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Standard Agglutination test

questions.text: Fever with pneumonia, sputum smear showing broad based budding fungi with double contoured cell wall. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Blastomyces

questions.text: A farmer presents with features of high fever, painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, vomiting, diarrhea, and hypotension. Which stain will help in the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Wayson’s stain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wayson’s stain is used for diagnosing bubonic plague caused by Yersinia pestis, as it highlights the bipolar staining (safety pin appearance) of the bacterium. This makes it an essential tool for confirming the diagnosis in cases with typical symptoms and risk factors.
  • ➤ Wayson’s stain
  • ➤ bubonic plague
  • ➤ bipolar staining

questions.text: To prevent swarming, the % agar in nutrient agar has to be increased at least to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 6%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To inhibit bacterial swarming on nutrient agar, the agar concentration should be increased to at least 6% to create a firm medium.
  • ➤ 6%

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl had splenomegaly, leucopenia, step ladder pattern fever, and died in a few days. Longitudinal ulcers were found in the intestine. What should be the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Typhoid

questions.text: Pig tapeworm may cause more dangerous disease than beef tapeworm because:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CNS involvement

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pig tapeworm (Taenia solium) is more dangerous than the beef tapeworm (Taenia saginata) because it can cause neurocysticercosis, leading to CNS involvement and severe neurological symptoms.

questions.text: Fish acts as intermediate host in:
questions.explanation: Ans. A) D. latum

questions.text: Which one of the following is true?

options.label: C
options.text: Addition of selective substances in a solid medium is called enrichment media

questions.correct_answer: D. Nutrient broth is basal medium
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Nutrient broth is basal medium

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presented to the emergency with high-grade fever, chest pain, increased respiratory rate, and cough with expectoration. His sputum was sent to the laboratory for Gram staining, which showed the presence of pus cells and Gram-positive cocci in pairs. Which of the following will help in confirming
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bile solubility

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected pneumococcal pneumonia , where Gram-positive cocci in pairs are observed in a Gram stain, the bile solubility test is the appropriate diagnostic test to confirm Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • ➤ pneumococcal pneumonia
  • ➤ Gram-positive cocci in pairs
  • ➤ bile solubility test

questions.text: True regarding H. influenzae growth:

options.label: A
options.text: Growth in MacConkey and blood agar but not chocolate agar

options.label: B
options.text: Growth in MacConkey and chocolate agar but not blood agar

options.label: C
options.text: Growth in blood and chocolate agar but not MacConkey medium

options.label: D
options.text: Growth in MacConkey, blood and chocolate agar

questions.correct_answer: C. Growth in blood and chocolate agar but not MacConkey medium
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Growth in blood and chocolate agar but not MacConkey medium

questions.text: Which HPV causes Condyloma acuminatum. Most common cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) HPV 6 & 11

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HPV 6 and 11 are the most common causes of Condyloma acuminatum (genital warts) and are classified as low-risk HPV types.

questions.text: A child is presented with fever, conjunctivitis, and bluish white spots on the buccal mucosa. Four days later, she developed rashes. What is the characteristic feature of the virus that is responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) SS- enveloped RNA virus

questions.text: In a patient with Malaria, if fever has periodicity of 72 hours, which one of the following is likely to be the causative agent?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) P. malariae

questions.text: The Plasmodium species known for relapse in malaria is:
questions.correct_answer: C. P. vivax and P. ovale
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) P. vivax and P. ovale

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Relapse in malaria is specifically caused by P. vivax and P. ovale due to the presence of hypnozoites, which can reactivate after an initial treatment. Understanding the difference between relapse (due to dormant liver stages) and recrudescence (due to incomplete blood-stage treatment) is crucial for managing malaria.
  • ➤ Relapse
  • ➤ P. vivax and P. ovale
  • ➤ relapse
  • ➤ recrudescence

questions.text: True about antigenic drift:

options.label: D
options.text: Arises due to frame shift mutations

questions.explanation: Ans. B) Leads to seasonal epidemics

questions.text: Regarding Clostridium perfringens gas gangrene, which of the following is false?

options.label: D
options.text: Food poisoning strain of Cl. perfringens produces heat resistant spores

questions.correct_answer: C. Most common toxin is Hyaluronidase
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Most common toxin is Hyaluronidase

questions.text: The insect given in the image below is a vector of which of the following diseases?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Visceral leishmaniasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sandflies (e.g., Phlebotomus species) are vectors for leishmaniasis , including visceral leishmaniasis , where they transmit the Leishmania donovani parasite. Identification of the sandfly and its role in vector-borne diseases is crucial for diagnosis and control of leishmaniasis.
  • ➤ Sandflies
  • ➤ leishmaniasis
  • ➤ visceral leishmaniasis
  • ➤ Leishmania donovani

questions.text: Nontoxigenic C. diphtheriae changes to toxigenic C. diphtheriae by the help of a bacteriophage. By which method does this conversion occur?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lysogenic Conversion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The conversion of nontoxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae to a toxigenic strain capable of producing diphtheria toxin is achieved through lysogenic conversion , where a bacteriophage integrates its tox gene into the bacterial genome.
  • ➤ lysogenic conversion

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady with a 3-month history of progressive breathlessness and dyspnea was evaluated. Chest X-ray showed a cavitary lesion in the lower lobe of the lung. A lobectomy was performed, and histopathology revealed the following image. Identify the agent and how many layers it will have?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Echinococcus with 2 layers

questions.text: A diabetic patient suffers from a soft tissue infection, and microbiological examination reveals the infection is caused by fungi with aseptate and broad hyphae. Which of the following fungus is responsible for this infection?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mucor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mucor and related fungi in the Zygomycetes family are identified by their broad, aseptate hyphae and are known to cause mucormycosis , especially in diabetic patients with poor blood sugar control. Recognizing the characteristic hyphal structure is key to diagnosing this serious infection.
  • ➤ Mucor
  • ➤ Zygomycetes family
  • ➤ broad, aseptate hyphae
  • ➤ mucormycosis
  • ➤ diabetic patients

questions.text: Helminth implicated in causing pernicious anemia is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Diphyllobothrium latum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diphyllobothrium latum causes pernicious anemia by depleting vitamin B12 in the host’s intestine, while helminths like hookworm (Necator americanus or Ancylostoma duodenale) cause iron deficiency anemia .
  • ➤ pernicious anemia
  • ➤ iron deficiency anemia

questions.text: Image depicted below belongs to which of the following?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Wuchereria bancrofti

questions.text: A newborn premature baby was presented with bullous lesions on skin and a shin on the knee. X-ray shows periostitis. Best investigation for diagnosis is:
questions.correct_answer: A. VDRL from mother and baby
questions.explanation: Ans. A) VDRL from mother and baby

questions.text: A 20-year-old male with a history of fever, enlarged lymph nodes, and sore throat was suspected to have infectious mononucleosis and was ordered a Paul Bunnel test. Which of the following is the principle of the test?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Heterophile agglutination test

questions.text: Which of the following is microaerophilic?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Campylobacter

questions.text: A person presents with pneumonia. His sputum was sent for culture. The bacterium obtained was gram-positive cocci in chains and alpha-hemolytic colonies on sheep agar. Which of the following will help in confirming the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Optochin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Optochin sensitivity testing is used to differentiate Streptococcus pneumoniae (optochin-sensitive) from Streptococcus viridans group (optochin-resistant), especially in cases of pneumonia with alpha-hemolytic gram-positive cocci.

questions.text: In measles, the patient is infectious:

options.label: A
options.text: 3 days before to 4 days after the onset of rash

options.label: B
options.text: 4 days before to 3 days after the onset of rash

options.label: C
options.text: 4 days before to 5 days after the onset of rash

options.label: D
options.text: 5 days before to 4 days after the onset of rash

questions.correct_answer: C. 4 days before to 5 days after the onset of rash
questions.explanation: Ans. C. 4 days before to 5 days after the onset of rash

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a painless ulcer on the penis has a history of contact with a commercial sex worker. Dark ground microscopy of the discharge from the lesion is shown in the picture. Identify the disease.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Chancre

questions.text: A patient presented to an STD clinic with a painful genital ulcer and painful, soft nonindurated enlarged inguinal lymph node. Identify the pathogen:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Haemophilus ducreyi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A painful genital ulcer accompanied by painful, soft, non-indurated inguinal lymph nodes suggests chancroid , which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi . Recognizing the key features helps in differentiating it from other sexually transmitted infections like syphilis, donovanosis, and herpes.
  • ➤ painful genital ulcer
  • ➤ painful, soft, non-indurated inguinal lymph nodes
  • ➤ chancroid
  • ➤ Haemophilus ducreyi

questions.text: Swarming is seen in:
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Clostridium tetani

questions.text: Which is the mode of transmission and infective form of the parasite whose egg picture is given below?

options.label: B
options.text: Ingestion of egg contaminated in water

questions.correct_answer: B. Ingestion of egg contaminated in water
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Ingestion of egg contaminated in water

questions.text: A child with bull neck and membrane over tonsil. What is the mechanism of the toxin responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Inhibits Elongation Factor-2

questions.text: In HIV, the window period indicates:

options.label: A
options.text: Time period between infection and onset of first symptoms

options.label: B
options.text: Time period between infection and detection of antibodies against HIV

options.label: C
options.text: Time period between infection and minimum multiplication of the organism

options.label: D
options.text: Time period between infection and maximum multiplication of the organism

questions.correct_answer: B. Time period between infection and detection of antibodies against HIV
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Time period between infection and detection of antibodies against HIV

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The HIV window period is the time between infection and when antibodies become detectable. During this period, the person is highly infectious, but standard antibody tests may not yet show a positive result.

questions.text: A patient has painful tiny vesicular ulcers on the lips. A Tzanck smear was made from the scraping of the lesion. Identify the pathogen:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Herpes simplex virus (HSV-1) is the most common cause of painful vesicular ulcers on the lips , and a Tzanck smear showing multinucleated giant cells is a key diagnostic finding.
  • ➤ Herpes simplex virus
  • ➤ painful vesicular ulcers on the lips
  • ➤ Tzanck smear
  • ➤ multinucleated giant cells

questions.text: Both intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Measles virus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Both intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion are seen in: - Measles and CMV
  • • Both intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion are seen in: - Measles and CMV

questions.text: A 40-year-old man underwent kidney transplantation. Two months after transplantation, he developed fever and features suggestive of bilateral diffuse interstitial pneumonitis. Which of the following is the most likely etiologic agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cytomegalovirus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cytomegalovirus is a common cause of diffuse interstitial pneumonitis in post-transplant patients, particularly within the first few months following transplantation due to their immunocompromised state.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with fever and cervical lymphadenopathy. Oral examination shows a grey membrane on the right tonsil extending to the anterior pillar. Which of the following medium will be ideal for the culture of the throat swab for a rapid identification of the pathogen?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Loffler’s serum slope

questions.text: A vitreous aspirate from a case of metastatic endophthalmitis on culture yields Gram-positive round to oval cells, 12-14 μm in size. The aspirate on Gram staining shows the presence of pseudohyphae. Which of the following is the most likely etiological agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Candida

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of pseudohyphae with round to oval yeast cells in a Gram-positive fungal culture suggests an infection by Candida species, which can cause metastatic endophthalmitis in immunocompromised individuals.
  • ➤ pseudohyphae
  • ➤ round to oval yeast cells

questions.text: A rose gardener has multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along the lymphatics. Most common fungus responsible is:
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Sporothrix schenckii

questions.text: The following is false about Adenovirus:

options.label: C
options.text: Hemorrhagic cystitis is due to type 11,21

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) SSDNA virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenovirus is a double-stranded DNA virus, not a single-stranded DNA virus. Remember, only Parvovirus among DNA viruses is single-stranded.

questions.text: A patient was presented to the hospital with severe hydrophobia. Corneal scrapings from the patient are obtained. What test should be done on this specimen for a diagnosis of Rabies?

options.label: C
options.text: Antibodies to rabies virus by Indirect Immunofluorescence

questions.explanation: Ans. A) RT-PCR for Rabies virus

questions.text: The following lesions were seen in a child. The patient is suffering from a disease caused by which of these viruses?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Coxsackie A virus

questions.text: Which is the first antibody synthesized in fetal life?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) IgM

questions.text: Wood’s Lamp is used in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pityriasis versicolor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wood’s lamp is particularly helpful in diagnosing Pityriasis versicolor , as the affected skin shows a yellow-green fluorescence under UV light, aiding in the identification of this fungal infection.
  • ➤ Wood’s lamp
  • ➤ Pityriasis versicolor
  • ➤ yellow-green fluorescence

questions.text: A patient admitted to an ICU is on central venous line for the last one week. He is on ceftazidime and amikacin. After 7 days of antibiotics, he develops a spike of fever and his blood culture is positive for gram positive cocci in chains, which are catalase negative. Following this, vancomycin was started but the culture remained positive for the same organism even after 2 weeks of therapy. The most likely organism causing infection is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Enterococcus faecalis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enterococcus faecalis , especially vancomycin-resistant strains (VRE), are known to cause nosocomial infections , particularly in ICU settings, and show resistance to multiple antibiotics, including vancomycin.
  • ➤ Enterococcus faecalis
  • ➤ nosocomial infections

questions.text: Resistance to HIV infection occurs due to mutation of:
questions.explanation: Ans. A) CCR 5

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient is presented with necrotic pneumonia. Sputum culture reveals mucoid lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey medium. What is the organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Klebsiella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mucoid, lactose-fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar, especially in the context of pneumonia in a chronic alcoholic, are strongly indicative of Klebsiella pneumoniae.

questions.text: Winter bottom sign is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) African trypanosomiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Winterbottom sign (posterior cervical lymphadenopathy) is a clinical feature specific to West African trypanosomiasis, caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense.

questions.text: Neonates have hepatosplenomegaly. His urine was stained with Giemsa stain which revealed owl’s eye appearance inclusions. Which will be the most probable cause?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) CMV

questions.text: A patient is suffering from a painful vesicular eruption at the T-4 dermatome. The cause is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Herpes zoster

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Herpes zoster (shingles) presents as a painful vesicular rash restricted to a single dermatome (e.g., T-4) and occurs due to the reactivation of latent varicella-zoster virus (VZV) in sensory ganglia. It is distinguished by its unilateral presentation and does not cross the midline.
  • ➤ Herpes zoster (shingles)
  • ➤ painful vesicular rash
  • ➤ single dermatome
  • ➤ reactivation of latent varicella-zoster virus (VZV)

questions.text: Which of these need V factor?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) H. paraphrophilus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ H. paraphrophilus requires only V factor (NAD) for growth, while other species like H. influenzae and H. aegyptius need both X and V factors.

questions.text: False About the mechanism of bacterial toxins:

options.label: A
options.text: Cholera toxin acts by inhibition of guanylcyclase

options.label: C
options.text: Shiga toxin act by inhibiting protein synthesis

options.label: D
options.text: Diphtheria toxin act by inhibiting protein synthesis

questions.correct_answer: A. Cholera toxin acts by inhibition of guanylcyclase
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cholera toxin acts by inhibition of guanylcyclase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholera toxin stimulates adenyl cyclase , leading to increased cAMP . Botulinum toxin inhibits acetylcholine release , resulting in flaccid paralysis. Shiga and Diphtheria toxins inhibit protein synthesis , causing cellular damage
  • ➤ Cholera toxin stimulates adenyl cyclase , leading to increased cAMP .
  • ➤ Cholera toxin
  • ➤ adenyl cyclase
  • ➤ cAMP
  • ➤ Botulinum toxin inhibits acetylcholine release , resulting in flaccid paralysis.
  • ➤ Botulinum toxin
  • ➤ acetylcholine release
  • ➤ Shiga and Diphtheria toxins inhibit protein synthesis , causing cellular damage
  • ➤ Shiga
  • ➤ Diphtheria toxins
  • ➤ protein synthesis

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with features of acute meningoencephalitis in the casualty. His CSF on wet mount microscopy revealed motile unicellular microorganisms. The most likely organism is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Naegleria fowleri

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute meningoencephalitis with motile trophozoites in the CSF is characteristic of Naegleria fowleri, a free-living amoeba that can cause primary amoebic meningoencephalitis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old boy went for trekking and came back with a history of rash. Weil-Felix test revealed elevated Ox 2 and Ox 19 titers. What is the most likely organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rickettsia rickettsii

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When interpreting the Weil-Felix test for Rickettsial infections:
  • ➤ OX19 and OX2 positivity indicates Rocky Mountain spotted fever (Rickettsia rickettsii) or Mediterranean spotted fever (Rickettsia conorii). A history of trekking and tick exposure points to Rickettsia rickettsii as the most likely cause.
  • ➤ OX19 and OX2 positivity indicates Rocky Mountain spotted fever (Rickettsia rickettsii) or Mediterranean spotted fever (Rickettsia conorii).
  • ➤ OX19 and OX2 positivity
  • ➤ A history of trekking and tick exposure points to Rickettsia rickettsii as the most likely cause.

questions.text: Reduviid bug is a vector for the transmission of:
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Chagas disease

questions.text: A 23-year-old male had unprotected sexual intercourse with a commercial sex worker. Two weeks later, he developed a painless, indurated ulcer on the glans that exuded clear serum on pressure. Inguinal lymph nodes in both groins were enlarged and not tender. The most appropriate diagnostic test is:

options.label: B
options.text: Dark field microscopy of ulcer discharge

options.label: C
options.text: Giemsa stain of lymph node aspirate

questions.correct_answer: B. Dark field microscopy of ulcer discharge
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dark field microscopy of ulcer discharge

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with a painless, indurated ulcer on the genitalia and enlarged, non-tender lymph nodes , dark field microscopy is the best initial diagnostic test for detecting Treponema pallidum in primary syphilis.
  • ➤ painless, indurated ulcer
  • ➤ enlarged, non-tender lymph nodes
  • ➤ dark field microscopy

questions.text: A child with 3 years of age presents with weakness with Hb level <5 g/dL. History of blood loss in stool was present. What would be the causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hookworm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hookworms, specifically Necator americanus and Ancylostoma duodenale, cause chronic intestinal blood loss leading to iron deficiency anemia, especially in children.

questions.text: Neil Mooser reaction or tunica reaction is useful to differentiate between:
questions.correct_answer: A. R. prowazekii and R. typhi
questions.explanation: Ans. A) R. prowazekii and R. typhi

questions.text: Which of the following egg contains three pairs of hooklets and polar filaments but is bile nonstained?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) H. nana

questions.text: A 33-year-old sexually active male is experiencing urethral discharge for the past 8 months, along with a burning sensation during urination. A Gram-stained smear of a urethral swab sample is shown below:The causative organism is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of Gram-negative, intracellular diplococci in a urethral swab from a patient with urethritis is characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

questions.text: A patient with benign hypertrophy of the prostate (BPH) was admitted to the hospital for 3 weeks. He subsequently developed a suspected catheter-associated urinary tract infection (UTI). The tip of the catheter was sent for culture, and the growth was observed on blood agar. After 24 hours, the blood agar showed the following appearance. What is the likely causative agent for the UTI?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Proteus mirabilis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Swarming motility observed on blood agar is characteristic of Proteus mirabilis, a common cause of catheter-associated UTIs.

questions.text: All statements are true about mycetoma except:

options.label: B
options.text: Surgery is important component of treatment

options.label: D
options.text: Diagnosis can be made by examination of lesion

questions.correct_answer: A. Eumycetoma is caused by bacteria
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Eumycetoma is caused by bacteria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eumycetoma is caused by fungi , not bacteria, distinguishing it from actinomycetoma , which is bacterial. Treatment of mycetoma typically involves surgical intervention and is generally painless despite the chronic nature of the disease.
  • ➤ Eumycetoma
  • ➤ fungi
  • ➤ actinomycetoma
  • ➤ surgical intervention

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of dysphagia. On UGI Endoscopy, a diagnosis of esophageal candidiasis was made. The organism obtained from the sample was cultured on a specialized media, and the finding shown in the image was visible on microscopy of the culture. What phenomenon is shown below?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Germ tube formation

questions.text: True about Botulinum toxin:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Interfere with cholinergic transmission

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Botulinum toxin works by blocking the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, leading to flaccid paralysis . It specifically interferes with cholinergic transmission but has no effect on the CNS.
  • ➤ Botulinum toxin
  • ➤ blocking the release of acetylcholine
  • ➤ flaccid paralysis
  • ➤ cholinergic transmission

questions.text: EBV receptors is:
questions.explanation: Ans. A) CD 21

questions.text: All are Koch’s postulates except:

options.label: A
options.text: A microorganism should be constantly associated with the lesions of the disease

options.label: B
options.text: It should be possible to isolate the bacterium in pure culture from the lesions

options.label: C
options.text: Inoculation of such pure culture into laboratory animals should reproduce the lesions

options.label: D
options.text: Administration of broad-spectrum antimicrobial agent dependably eradicates the organisms and cures the diseases

questions.correct_answer: D. Administration of broad-spectrum antimicrobial agent dependably eradicates the organisms and cures the diseases
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Administration of broad-spectrum antimicrobial agent dependably eradicates the organisms and cures the diseases

questions.text: Eggs of which of the following parasites cause intense pruritus in the perianal skin:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Enterobius vermicularis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intense nocturnal pruritus in the perianal region is a classic symptom of Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) infection, especially in children.

questions.text: A person working in an abattoir presented with a pustule on his hand that progressed to form an ulcer. The smear is taken from the ulcer and sent to the laboratory for investigation. Which of the following is the best stain to determine the causative agent of the ulcer?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Trichrome methylene blue

questions.text: A person received complete immunization against tetanus 10 years ago. Now he presents with a clean wound without any lacerations from an injury sustained 2.5 hours ago. He should now be given:

options.label: D
options.text: Human Tet globulin and single dose of toxoid

questions.correct_answer: B. Single dose of tetanus toxoid
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Single dose of tetanus toxoid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a clean, non-tetanus-prone wound in a person with complete tetanus immunization over 10 years ago , the appropriate intervention is to administer a single booster dose of tetanus toxoid to maintain protection against tetanus.
  • ➤ clean, non-tetanus-prone wound
  • ➤ complete tetanus immunization over 10 years ago
  • ➤ single booster dose of tetanus toxoid

questions.text: HBV and HDV false is:

options.label: B
options.text: HDV causes more serious infection due to superinfection

options.label: C
options.text: HDV cannot infect in absence of HBV

questions.correct_answer: D. HDV is a DNA virus
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) HDV is a DNA virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HDV is an RNA virus that relies on HBV for its replication and infectivity. It is not a DNA virus.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presented with fever and chills for 3 days. On examination, he was found to have delayed skin pinch time and dry oral mucosa. A peripheral blood smear revealed the following picture. Identify the pathogen involved:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Plasmodium falciparum is identified in blood smears by the presence of multiple ring forms within a single RBC and banana-shaped gametocytes . These features distinguish it from other species of Plasmodium and Babesia , making it the most likely cause of severe malaria in this patient.
  • ➤ Plasmodium falciparum
  • ➤ multiple ring forms within a single RBC
  • ➤ banana-shaped gametocytes
  • ➤ Babesia

questions.text: Which of the following is not caused by Parvovirus:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Roseola infantum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Roseola infantum is caused by HHV-6, not by Parvovirus B19, which is responsible for conditions like aplastic anemia, nonimmune hydrops fetalis, and erythema infectiosum.

questions.text: A woman with infertility receives an ovary transplant from her sister who is an identical twin. What type of graft is this?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Isograft

questions.text: An army jawan posted in remote forest area following a tick bite had fever and headache. His fever was 104 °F and pulse was 70 per min. He had an erythematous lesion of about 1 cm on the leg surrounded by small vesicles, along with generalized lymphadenopathy at the time of presentation to the referral hospital. His blood sample was collected to perform serology for the diagnosis of Rickettsial disease. Which one of the following results in Weil-Felix reaction will be diagnostic in this clinical setting?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) High OX – 19 and OX – 2

questions.text: A woman presented with dome-shaped warty lesions with a dimple at the center on her forehead for 2 months. Similar lesions were noticed in her daughter (image given). What is the causative agent?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Poxvirus

questions.text: Identify the organism from its egg in the picture:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Necator americanus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of non-bile stained, transparent eggs with four blastomeres is indicative of hookworm species like Necator americanus or Ancylostoma duodenale.

questions.text: Identify the organism which shows effacement and attachment of intestinal cells as shown below:
questions.explanation: Ans. A) EPEC
